OXBAR(1) General Commands Manual OXBAR(1)

NAME

oxbar —
configurable X11 status bar for OpenBSD

SYNOPSIS

oxbar [
-H
] [
-F config-file
] [
-x xloc
] [
-y yloc
] [
-w width
] [
-h height
] [
-f font
] [
-m margins
] [
-p paddings
] [
-s spacing
] [
-c header-style
] [
-t time-format
] [
-W widgets
] [
-S key=value
] [
theme
]

DESCRIPTION

oxbar is a X11 status bar for OpenBSD showing various system stats, has a configurable display, and works out-of-the-box on most modern window managers in an intuitive fashion. It supports FreeType font rendering and styling, true transparency & alpha blending on all UI components (including the background), and a simple configuration format that can concisely support multiple themes.

Overview of Configuring oxbar

All configurable properties in oxbar can be set via the command line or a configuration file. The default configuration file is $HOME/.oxbar.conf but that can be overridden with the -F config-file command line option. When using a configuration file, the file can be reread at runtime by sending a SIGHUP signal to oxbar.
Setting configurable properties is always of the form property=value, either from the command line or configuration file. Many properties have intuitive shortcuts on the command line. See the section CONFIGURATION for a list of all configurable properties.

Command Line Flags

oxbar supports the following command line flags:
-H
Print brief help information regarding the supported command line flags.
-F config-file
Load config-file instead of the default configuration file $HOME/.oxbar.conf.
-x xloc
Sets the x coordinate, in pixels, of the upper-left corner of the window.
Corresponding configurable property: window.x.
-y yloc
Sets the y coordinate, in pixels, of the upper-left corner of the window. If set to -1, the window will be aligned to the bottom of the display.
Corresponding configurable property: window.y.
-w width
Sets the width, in pixels, of the window. If set to -1, the window will span the full width of the X display.
Corresponding configurable property: window.w.
-h height
Sets the height, in pixels, of the window. If set to -1, the window's height will be derived from the font description used and any margins/paddings specified.
Corresponding configurable property: window.h.
-f font
A string specifying the font, and its styling, used throughout the display of oxbar. This supports a very flexible format as it's parsed by pango_font_description_from_string(3). See the section SPECIFYING FONTS below for details on the format and samples.
Corresponding configurable property: font.desc.
-m margins
Sets the margins, in pixels, surrounding each widget shown in oxbar. The margins are the same for every widget. The margins can be specified for the top, right, bottom, and left regions around a widget, in that order, by providing a quoted string with four unsigned integers. E.g. -m “10 20 10 20” would set the top and bottom margins to 10 pixels, and the right and left margins to 20 pixels. Providing a single number, such as -m 10, will set all components to 10 pixels. This follows CSS style conventions.
Corresponding configurable property: gui.margin.
-p paddings
Sets the paddings, in pixels, within each widget shown in oxbar. The paddings are the same for every widget, and can be specified using the same format as the -m margins option (above).
Corresponding configurable property: gui.padding.
-s spacing
Sets the spacing, in pixels, between each widget in the display.
Corresponding configurable property: gui.widget_spacing.
-c header-style
oxbar can show colored “headers” above/below each widget, within the padding region of each widget. These help quickly find/identify widgets visually. The color can be specified per-widget. This option instructs if/where to render such headers. It accepts the following string options:
none
Do not render any header bars.
above
Render header bars in the top padding region of each widget (they will be as wide as the top padding of each widget).
below
Render header bars in the bottom padding region of each widget.
Corresponding configurable property: gui.header_style.
-t time-format
Sets the format used by the time widget when rendering the date/time. This is any string accepted by strftime(3).
Corresponding configurable property: time.format.
-W widgets
A string specifying the list of widgets to be rendered by oxbar and where they should appear. See the section SPECIFYING WIDGETS below on the format of this string.
Corresponding configurable property: widgets.
-S “property=value”
Set any configurable property to value in oxbar. This is a generic way to set any aspect of oxbar at the command line. Note that all such options could also be set in the oxbar configuration file. This option is useful for testing changes/tweaks to oxbar. See the section CONFIGURATION below for a list of all such properties that can be set.
As an example, the flag -S “window.x = 100” would set the x location (in pixels) of the upper-left corner of the display to x. This would be equivalent to either -x 100 at the command line, or a line like window.x = 100 in the configuration file.
theme
An optional theme name to load from the configuration file. If a theme is specified and no configuration file is found (either specified via -F config-file or using the default $HOME/.oxbar.conf) oxbar will report an error and exit.
When specified, any lines in the configuration file after a line like [theme], and before any other theme definition, will be loaded, along with any lines before the first theme definition (considered global options). See the FILES section for full details.

ENVIRONMENT

HOME
The user's home directory, which oxbar will use to construct the name of the default configuration file to load ($HOME/.oxbar.conf) if no -F config-file command line parameter is set.

FILES

oxbar can optionally use a configuration file, whose format is described here. When using a configuration file, the file can be re-loaded and processed at runtime by sending a SIGHUP signal to oxbar.

Configuration File Location

By default oxbar will attempt to use $HOME/.oxbar.conf by using the $HOME environment variable. If that variable is not set, getpwuid(3) is used to try and determine the caller's home directory as a replacement for $HOME. If both of those fail, no default configuration file is loaded.
To load a different configuration file on startup, use the -F config-file command line flag.

Configuration File Format

The bulk of the configuration file contains lines like 
property = value
Most properties have a prefix (or “namespace”) that denote the scope of the property. As an example, a line like 
window.x = 100
would set the location of the main window's top-left corner to x (in pixels). And a block like 
window.bgcolor = "ff0000" 
time.bgcolor   = "00ff00"
would set the window's primary background color to red, but the background color for time widget to green (these are using 32-bit hex color codes, see the section SPECIFYING COLORS for details).
The configuration file is parsed with fparseln(3), and thus supports rich spacing and comments. Specifically,
  • Blank lines are ignored
  • Spacing within lines is liberal. All of the following are permitted and equivalent: 
    window.x=100 
window.x    =     100 
      window.x    =     100
  • Lines can be continued with a \ ending a line, such as: 
    window.x = \ 
           10
  • Anything after a # is considered a comment. 
    # this is a comment 
   # so is this 
window.x = 100    # set offset to 100 (this is a comment)

Using Themes

Themes provide a way to support multiple configurations of oxbar in a single file and load each optionally at the command line. This is useful if you run multiple instances of oxbar, say one configuration for the top of your display showing some widgets, and another configuration at the bottom of your display showing a different set of widgets.
Themes are a subset of a configuration file. They begin with a line like: 
[theme-name]
All lines after that are considered part of a theme named theme-name until either the end of the file or a new theme is defined.
To run oxbar and use a theme, simply provide the theme-name as the last parameter on the command line, like this: 
$ oxbar [options] theme-name
The following example configuration file is used below to illustrate the usage of themes. 
# global configuration (always loaded for any or no themes) 
font.desc = "DejaVu Sans Mono 20px" # font used everywhere 
font.fgcolor = "93a1a1"             # a light grey 
window.x = 0                        # align to left of display 
window.w = -1                       # align to bototm of display 
window.h = -1                       # derive height 
 
# start the "top" theme 
[top] 
widgets = "< nprocs cpulong | memory > net" 
window.y = 0                        # show at top of display 
 
# start the "bottom" theme 
[bottom] 
widgets = "< volume | time > battery" 
window.y = -1                       # show at bottom of display
Given the above configuration file, two theemse are defined: top and bottom. The lines that occur before any theme definition are considered global, and are always loaded for any, or no, theme. This is handy if some things (such as font) apply to all themes.
Using the above, the following two commands would launch two instances of oxbar, using their respective theme definitions. 
$ oxbar [options] top & 
$ oxbar [options] bottom &
The result is one instance (“top”) running at the top of the display with the 4 widgets (nprocs, cpulong, memory, and net) and another instance (“bottom”) running at the bottom of the display with 3 widgets (volume, time, and battery).

CONFIGURATION

This is a complete list of all configurable properties supported by oxbar. They can be set:
  • At the command line with -S property=value, where property is one of the properties listed below and value is the value you which to set it to, or
  • In the configuration file with a line like property=value. See the section FILES for more details on that format.

Useful Terminology

Many of the configurable properties have common suffixes, and knowing what they mean can help to understand their use. These suffixes are:
fgcolor
A foreground color, typically for text.
bgcolor
A background color, for the whole window or individual widgets.
hdcolor
A header color, typically denoting the header of each widget (the horizontal bars optionally shown above or below each widget). These properties allow you to color each widget's bar separately.
pgcolor
The color of a progress indicator, typically a progress bar (like those used for the battery and volume widgets).
What follows is the list of all configurable properties in oxbar.

Font Properties

These control core font used throughout the display and what the default color of all text is.
font.desc
Set's the font and styles to be used throughout the display. See the section SPECIFYING FONTS for full details.
Default value: “DejaVu sans mono 16px”
font.fgcolor
Set's the default foreground color for all text in the display. Note the foreground color of each widget can be overridden (see other options below).
Default value: “#93a1a1”

Window Properties

These control with window placement, dimensions, color, and window-manager name.
window.x
The x coordinate, in pixels, of the upper-left corner of the display.
Default value: “0”
window.y
The y coordinate, in pixels, of the upper-left corner of the display. If set to -1, the window will be aligned to the bottom of the display.
Default value: “0”
window.w
The width, in pixels, of the display. If set to -1, the window will span the full width of the X display.
Default value: “-1”
window.h
The height, in pixels, of the display. If set to -1, derive the height from the font described and any margins/paddings specified.
Default value: “-1”
window.wname
The name of the window created as identified by the X11 display.
Default value: “oxbar”
window.bgcolor
The background color of the main display. To achieve a transparent display, use alpha blending here by explicitly setting an alpha component in the value. See the section SPECIFYING COLORS for how to do that.
Default value: “0a0a0a”

GUI Properties

The “GUI” of oxbar is just an orchestrator of widgets, in that it only controls where/how they are rendered. These properties are specific to that, spanning all widgets and the display.
widgets
The list of widgets to be rendered, and where. See the section SPECIFYING WIDGETS for full details.
Default value: “nprocs cpuslong memory net > battery volume time”
gui.margin
The margins, in pixels, surrounding each widget. The margins can be specified for the top, right, bottom, and left regions around a widget, in that order, by providing a quoted string with four unsigned integers. E.g. -m “10 20 10 20” would set the top and bottom margins to 10 pixels, and the right and left margins to 20 pixels. Providing a single number, such as -m 10 will set all components to 10 pixels. This follows CSS style conventions.
Default value: “2”
gui.padding
The paddings, in pixels, within each widget. The value follows the same format as the gui.margins property above.
Default value: “5”
gui.header_style
oxbar can show colored “headers” above/below each widget, within the padding region of each widget. These help quickly find/identify widgets visually. The color can be specified per-widget. This option instructs if/where to render such headers. It accepts the following string options:
none
Do not render any header bars.
above
Render header bars in the top padding region of each widget (they will be as wide as the top padding of each widget).
below
Render header bars in the bottom padding region of each widget.
Default value: “below”
gui.widget_bgcolor
The background color for every widget. Useful if you want each widget to have the same background color separate from the main window's background color. If unset (or set to “”) then the value is unused.
Default value: “”
gui.widget_spacing
The spacing, in pixels, between each widget in the display.
Default value: “20”

Battery Widget

These properties configure the battery widget, showing charging & capacity status.
battery.hdcolor
The header color for this widget.
Default value: “b58900”
battery.bgcolor
The background color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to gui.widget_bgcolor if set, or window.bgcolor otherwise).
battery.fgcolor
The foreground color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to font.fgcolor ).
battery.fgcolor_unplugged
Color of the leading text when unplugged. Useful to highlight when on battery.
Default value: “dc322f”
battery.chart_width
Width (in pixels) of the progress bar.
Default value: “7”
battery.chart_bgcolor
Background color of the progress bar chart.
Default value: “dc322f”
battery.chart_pgcolor
Progress color of the progress bar chart.
Default value: “859900”

CPUs Widget

These properties configure the CPU widgets (which includes the cpu, cpulong, and cpushort widgets), showing a breakdown of CPU usage by core.
cpus.hdcolor
The header color for this widget.
Default value: “6c71c4”
cpus.bgcolor
The background color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to gui.widget_bgcolor if set, or window.bgcolor otherwise).
cpus.fgcolor
The foreground color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to font.fgcolor ).
cpus.chart_bgcolor
Background color of the chart.
Default values: “333333”
cpus.chart_color_system
Color of the system component of the charts.
Default value: “ff0000”
cpus.chart_color_interrupt
Color of the interrupt component of the charts.
Default value: “ffff00”
cpus.chart_color_user
Color of the user component of the charts.
Default value: “3333ff”
cpus.chart_color_nice
Color of the nice component of the charts.
Default value: “ff00ff”
cpus.chart_color_spin
Color of the spin component of the charts.
Default value: “00ffff”
cpus.chart_color_idle
Color of the idle component of the charts.
Default value: “859900”

Memory Widget

These properties configure the memory widget, showing a breakdown of memory usage.
memory.hdcolor
The header color for this widget.
Default value: “d33682”
memory.bgcolor
The background color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to gui.widget_bgcolor if set, or window.bgcolor otherwise).
memory.fgcolor
The foreground color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to font.fgcolor ).
memory.chart_bgcolor
Background color of the chart.
Default values: “333333”
memory.chart_color_free
Color of the free memory component of the chart and text.
Default value: “859900”
memory.chart_color_total
Color of the total memory component of the chart and text.
Default value: “bbbb00”
memory.chart_color_active
Color of the active memory component of the chart and text.
Default value: “dc322f”

Number Processes Widget

These properties configure the nprocs widget, showing the number of processes.
nprocs.hdcolor
The header color for this widget.
Default value: “dc322f”
nprocs.bgcolor
The background color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to gui.widget_bgcolor if set, or window.bgcolor otherwise).
nprocs.fgcolor
The foreground color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to font.fgcolor ).

Network Widget

These properties configure the network widget, showing the bytes in/out on the egress interface.
net.hdcolor
The header color for this widget.
Default value: “268bd2”
net.bgcolor
The background color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to gui.widget_bgcolor if set, or window.bgcolor otherwise).
net.fgcolor
The foreground color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to font.fgcolor ).
net.inbound_chart_color_bgcolor
Background color of the inbound traffic chart.
Default value: “859900”
net.inbound_chart_color_pgcolor
Progress color of the inbound traffic chart.
Default value: “157ad2”
net.inbound_text_fgcolor
Text color of the inbound traffic number.
Default value: “157ad2”
net.outbound_chart_color_bgcolor
Background color of the outbound traffic chart.
Default value: “859900”
net.outbound_chart_color_pgcolor
Progress color of the outbound traffic chart.
Default value: “dc322f”
net.outbound_text_fgcolor
Text color of the outbound traffic number.
Default value: “dc322f”

Time Widget

These properties configure the time widget, showing the date/time.
time.hdcolor
The header color for this widget.
Default value: “859900”
time.bgcolor
The background color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to gui.widget_bgcolor if set, or window.bgcolor otherwise).
time.fgcolor
The foreground color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to font.fgcolor ).
time.format
The format to use when displaying the date/time. Any string by strftime(3) is supported.
Default value: “%a %b %d %Y %I:%M:%S %p”

Volume Widget

These properties configure the volume widget, showing the current volume levels.
volume.hdcolor
The header color for this widget.
Default value: “cb4b16”
volume.bgcolor
The background color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to gui.widget_bgcolor if set, or window.bgcolor otherwise).
volume.fgcolor
The foreground color for this widget.
Default value: unset (fallback to font.fgcolor ).
volume.chart_width
Width (in pixels) of the progress bar.
Default value: “7”
volume.chart_bgcolor
Background color of the progress bar chart.
Default value: “dc322f”
volume.chart_pgcolor
Progress color of the progress bar chart.
Default value: “859900”

SPECIFYING FONTS

The font used by oxbar, and styling for it, is described and set using the font.desc property which is a string such as “helvetica 12px”. Its value is passed directly to Pango through the pango_font_description_from_string(3) API, and will thus accept any value that API accepts (which is quite expressive). All text rendered in oxbar will be done using the font loaded from that description.
See the documentation of that API for full details. In summary, the format of the string is a space separated list of the form 
FONT-FAMILY [STYLE | VARIANT | WEIGHT]* SIZEpx
where FONT-FAMILY is the name of the font family desired, optionally followed by some number of style/variant/weight modifiers (like italic, bold, heavy, light, etc). The SIZE is then specified in pixels. Note that oxbar currently requires the font to ALWAYS BE SPECIFIED IN PIXELS, and thus should always have the ‘px’ suffix on the size component.
CAVEAT: ALL FONTS SHOULD EXPLICITLY STATE PIXEL SIZING (px)
Some examples:
“fixed 16px”
Specifies the default fixed-width (monospaced) font for the system, at 16 pixels in height.
“Helvetica italic 16px”
Specifies the italic variant of the Helvetica font, sized at 16 pixels in height.
“DejaVu Sans Mono bold 20px”
Uses the monospaced and bold variant combination of the DejaVu font (requires package to be installed), sized at 20 pixels in height.

SPECIFYING COLORS

All colors in the configuration of oxbar are ultimately resolved to 32-bit color pairs of red, green, blue, and alpha values. All colors are specified as either 3 or 6 character hex codes without transparency, or 4 or 8 character hex codes with transparency.
Some examples are:
f00
Solid red, completely opaque
f008
Red, about half opaque / half transparent
ff0000
Also solid red (same as f00)
ff000088
Red, about half opaque / half transparent
The strings specifying these can optionally include a leading # symbol, though in the configuration file that must be escaped to prevent that character being interpreted as the start of a comment.

Note on True Transparency

oxbar supports true transparency / alpha blending on the main window by specifying a transparent color to the window.bgcolor property, such as window.bgcolor=5558. For this support to work, however, your window manager must support true transparency and may need a compositing manager running for the transparency to function. On the base install of OpenBSD this is xcompmgr(1), though compton(1) from ports is often easier to setup and configure.

SPECIFYING WIDGETS

The configurable property used to control which widgets are shown, and where, is widgets, and this section describes how to configure that property.
The property is simply a string containing a list of space-separated widget names (such as “time”, “memory”, etc), and some special characters that control the alignment of those widgets within the display. A setting such as 
widgets = "time volume battery"
would show the time, volume, and then battery widgets, in that order. They would also be shown left-aligned (growing from the left-most side of the window) as that's the default display alignment. The next subsection describes how to alter that.
Note that the widgets property can also be set on the command line using the -W flag. The above example could be specified on the command line with simply: 
oxbar -W "time volume battery"

Specifying Widget Alignment

The following characters in the widgets value string can alter the alignment of subsequent widgets specified:
<
All subsequent widgets are left-aligned, growing from the left-most edge of the display. This is the default alignment and thus not strictly required.
>
All subsequent widgets are right-aligned, growing from the right-most edge of the display.
|
All subsequent widgets are centered, so that the list of widgets appears in the exact center of the display.
As an example, the following setting 
widgets = "nprocs cpu memory net | time > battery volume"
would show the nprocs, cpu, memory, and net widgets on the left, a centered time widget, and then the battery and volume widgets on the right.

Available Widgets

This is the list of all available widgets.
NAME
DESCRIPTION
battery
This widget shows the battery status. It starts with the string "BAT" if running on battery or "AC" if plugged-in. It then shows a progress bar indicating the battery charge percentage and a corresponding text value for that percentage.
Corresponding configurable properties: battery.*.
cpu
This widget shows an overview, with charts, of CPU utilization. For each CPU it shows a historical histogram (spanning the last 60 seconds) breaking down the usage of that CPU (for user, system, idle, etc time), followed by the latest percentage idle time.
Corresponding configurable properties: cpus.*.
cpulong
Similar to the cpu widget above, only after each chart all CPU state percentages are printed, not just idle (so system, interrupt, user, nice, spin, and idle, in that order).
Corresponding configurable properties: cpus.*.
cpushort
This widget is a very brief, text-only display of CPU utilization. For each CPU, the percentage time non-idle is printed. That is all.
Corresponding configurable properties: cpus.*.
memory
This widget shows a breakdown of memory usage over time. It includes a historical histogram (spanning the last 60 seconds) showing a breakdown of the active, total, and free memory utilization, followed by text restating the latest sampled values for each (as raw memory values, not percentages).
Corresponding configurable properties: memory.*.
net
This widget shows a very brief overview of the network utilization on the egress interface. It shows two historical charts plotting the number of bytes inbound/outbound on that interface, for the past 60 seconds, followed by a textual representation of the latest sample of that activity.
Corresponding configurable properties: net.*.
nprocs
This widget simply shows the number of processes. That is all. Useful if you work on something that uses fork(2) a lot and you frequently fork-bomb yourself.
Corresponding configurable properties: nprocs.*.
time
This widget shows the current date/time.
Corresponding configurable properties: time.*.
volume
This widget shows the current volume. It includes a progress bar indicating the percentage of the current volume setting followed by a textual representation of that percentage.
Corresponding configurable properties: volume.*.

SEE ALSO

compton(1), xcompmgr(1), fparseln(3), getpwuid(3), strftime(3)
In addition, the following libraries are heavily utilized by oxbar:
https://xcb.freedesktop.org
XCB is a MIT licensed X11 client library used by oxbar to connect to an X11 display, render the window, and handle events.
https://www.pango.org
Pango is a LGPL licensed text layout and font rendering engine used by oxbar to load, render, and style fonts. Pango supports most modern fonts and font features.
https://cairographics.org
Cairo is a LGPL licensed vector graphics rendering library used by oxbar for all graphics rendering.

STANDARDS

oxbar is written natively on OpenBSD. It adheres to a strict C89 standard on the base clang(1) compiler, and builds/runs cleanly with “-std=c89 -Wall -Wextra -Werror”. Additionally, the make(1) targets scan-build and cppcheck run those tools, respectively, and should remain error/warning-free.
style(9) is mostly followed, but there's still work there to be done.
If interested in contributing, see the following link for tips on navigating the code base and getting started adding stats, widgets, etc. Care has been taken to make adding new stats and widgets easy.
https://github.com/ryanflannery/oxbar/CONTRIBUTING.md
The github repo is the place to submit bugs/changes/threats, and is located at: https://github.com/ryanflannery/oxbar

HISTORY

oxbar started as xstatbar, first written in 2006 as a status-bar that would work reasonably well for OpenBSD. It was written on a Friday and Saturday evening and had many, many bugs/shortcomings/etc. It was further hacked over a few years to support a handful of new features and widgets, but the term “hacked” there undervalues the level of code shit-hattery done to “Make-It-Work!”. I have personally received much derision because of that, and oxbar is an attempt to eliminate that.
Shaming works 'yo.

AUTHORS

oxbar is written and maintained by Ryan Flannery <ryan.flannery@gmail.com> or https://ryanflannery.net.
October 31, 2018 OpenBSD 6.4
